fields.physical_description:
The whole is made of various wood; simple carved and polished. The main part is a rectangular block of wood shaped as an `n' with the slot running the length. Towards the front of the block is a light wood knob which is attached to a bar running the length of the slot and protruding out at the back. At the back end is an upright of light wood with a stripy  grain nailed on. It has a pair of arms on a wooden pegs and on the top is glued a `cat' shaped head with the face marked with black pen lines. Between the paws is a mask showing another `cat' face decorated in red; white and black to represent a growling cat with its mouth open. Pegged to the end of the protruding bar and glued into a small hole at the back of the right arm is a length of black thread. When the knob is depressed; the end of the bar lowers; pulls the thread which causes the arms and the mask to lift and cover the face of the cat's head changing its countenence from a happy to an angry face. The tail of the cat is a twisted length of black and white pipe cleaner glued into a hole in the back. 
ROBERT RACE; born 1943. After teaching science and running a teachers' centre; he started to make dolls' houses; miniature furniture and toys in 1978. Over the last few years; he has concentrated on moving toys and automata. He also works occasionally with teachers and children using toys as a resource for education in design and technology. He has contributed widely to exhibitions of contemporary toys including: Jul/Aug 1987 SUMMER MADNESS EXHIBITION; The Black Swan Guild; Frome Dec. 1988 CHRISTMAS EXHIBITION; Davies Memorial Gallery; Newtown Mar. 1989 MOVING TOYS; Davies Memorial Gallery; Newtown; Powys Dec. 1989 CHRISTMAS EXHIBITION; Davies Memorial Gallery; Newtown CHRISTMAS EXHIBITION; Wrexham Library Arts Centre CHRISTMAS EXHIBITION; Milligans Gallery; Storrington
Nov/Dec 1990 TOYS AND CURIOSITIES; The Black Swan Guild; Frome CHRISTMAS EXHIBITION; Oriel 31; Welshpool Apr/May 1991 BRITISH
TOYMAKERS `91; Hitchcocks'; Bath Oct. 1991 AUTUMN EXHIBITION; Museum of Automata; York Nov/Dec 1991 CHRISTMAS EXHIBITION; Oriel 31; Welshpool Nov/Dec 1992 CATS EXHIBITION; Hitchcocks'; Bath May/Jun 1993 OF GREEN DAYS IN FORESTS...; Hitchcocks'; Bath Sep. 1993 AUTOMATA; Country Works Gallery; Montgomery; Powys Nov/Dec 1993 FUN AND GAMES; Trelissick Gallery; Cornwall SIDESHOW; Ruthin Craft Centre; Ruthin; Clwyd WOTCHAMACALLITS AND THINGAMJIGS; Black Swan Guild; Frome Jan. 1994 ROBERT RACE: MOVING TOYS...; Quaker Gallery; London; WC2 Mar/Apr 1994 AUTOMATA; Crafts Council of Ireland; Dublin May/Jul 1994 THE BIRDS AND THE BEES; Hitchcocks'; Bath Jun/Jul 1994 AUTOMATA; Oriel 31; Welshpool In 1989; he won 3rd prize in the Paper Engineering competition run by the BBC series `Take Nobody's Word For It.' He was the winner of the British Toymakers' Guild TOYMAKERS CUP in 1991 and 1992; and winner of the Grand Prize in the 5th Hikimi Wooden Puzzle Competition (1992) in Japan. Commissions include mobile decorations at the Child Development Centre; Scott Hospital Plymouth and large interactive toys for the Dynamic Toys Touring Exhibition originated at Banbury Museum; 1992-4. ROBERT RACE 'Innocent toys; things of such dignity As we greet modern friends withal...' Antony & Cleopatra; Act V; sc. ii. I try to make things which move in simple but interesting ways. They are intended to appeal to both children and adults. I call them moving toys and simple automata. I use those terms very loosely. I greatly admire and enjoy the dynamic `folk' and `street' toys still made in many parts of the world; despite the relentless pressures toward mass production and  standardisation. In my own work I aspire firstly to their makers' vigorous imagery; secondly to their ingenious use of simple mechanisms; and thirdly to their active exploration and exploitation of the properties of
those natural and recycled materials that are readily and cheaply available in the locality.
